text: Project Safe Neighborhood (PSN)
label: BODY

text: Anti-Gang Initiative and
label: BODY

text: Community Prosecution/Reducing Gun Violence and Crime
label: BODY

text: General Application Guidelines
label: H1

text: he Nevada Department of Public Safety, Office of Criminal Justice Assistance (OCJA), is
label: BODY

text: the fiscal agent for the Project Safe Neighborhood (PSN).  Please review these guidelines
label: BODY

text: carefully to apply for funding. The Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance (CFDA) number
label: BODY

text: for the Anti-Gang Initiative solicitation is 16.744.  The CFDA number for the PSN Reducing
label: BODY

text: Gun Violence and Crime solicitation is 16.609.
label: BODY

text: The hyperlinks in the document will assist you in your application process.  Save your
label: BODY

text: documents regularly to prevent losing data.  At any time you can jump through the document by
label: BODY

text: using CTRL G, going to Bookmarks and selecting the area to jump to from the dropdown menu.
label: BODY

text: If you haven’t done so, save this document to your hard drive before continuing.
label: BODY

text: PSN GRANT APPLICATION DEADLINE 4:00 p.m., JUNE 8, 2007
label: BODY

text: Eligible Applicants
label: BODY

text: This program provides financial assistance to state and local units of government, educational
label: BODY

text: institutions, faith-based and other community organizations.
label: BODY

text: Funding Areas
label: BODY

text: Department of Justice has dedicated PSN to fund current and expanded comprehensive anti-
label: BODY

text: gang prevention and Community Prosecution/Gun Control efforts. The Anti-Gang Initiative
label: BODY

text: funds will enhance PSN task force efforts to combat gangs by building on the effective
label: BODY

text: strategies and partnerships developed under PSN.  The Community Prosecution/Gun Control
label: BODY

text: projects must target gun crime and violent offenders.  PSN's five essential elements:
label: BODY

text: 1) partnerships, 2) strategic planning, 3) training, 4) outreach, and 5) accountability. For
label: BODY

text: more on these elements, visit www.ncjrs.org/html/bja/205263/ . Additional guidance may be
label: BODY

text: found at http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/BJA/psngrants/
label: BODY

text: Grant Commencement and Duration
label: BODY

text: Grants will be awarded for a twenty-four month period.  Grant award period will be 10/01/2007
label: BODY

text: thru 09/30/2009 or as determined by OCJA.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: Match Requirements
label: BODY

text: There is no match requirement.
label: BODY

text: Grant Review and Selection Process
label: BODY

text: Eligible applications will be reviewed and evaluated by an independent review committee
label: BODY

text: selected by the U.S. Attorney’s Office. The committee will carefully review all sections of your
label: BODY

text: Application.  To avoid disqualification all areas must be concise and complete; certifications
label: BODY

text: must be signed and dated; objectives must be measurable.  If you have any questions, contact an
label: BODY

text: OCJA Program Manager for guidance. (contacts)
label: BODY

text: Reporting Requirements for Successful Applicants
label: BODY

text: Fiscal Reports:  A Fiscal Report of grant expenditures is required monthly whether or not
label: BODY

text: there were expenditures for the grant.  The report is due by the 15th of each month.
label: BODY

text: Failure to submit monthly fiscal reports will prevent reimbursement of grant expenses and
label: BODY

text: may jeopardize grant continuation.  This form is available on the OCJA web page at
label: BODY

text: http://www.ocj.nv.gov .
label: BODY

text: Progress Reports:  Quarterly progress reports are required of subgrantees.  Failure to submit
label: BODY

text: progress reports will jeopardize grant continuation.  Quarterly reports are due 30 days after
label: BODY

text: the close of each quarter (Due Dates: January 30th, April 30th,  July 30th and October 30th).
label: BODY

text: The final report is due by October 30th.  Forms are available on the OCJA web page at
label: BODY

text: http://www.ocj.nv.gov .
label: BODY

text: Project Evaluation:  Forty-five days (November 15th ) after the close of the grant,
label: BODY

text: subgrantees are required to supply OCJA with an evaluation of the program for which grant
label: BODY

text: funds were awarded.  This evaluation will be an important part of determining future
label: BODY

text: funding.
label: BODY

text: Supplanting
label: BODY

text: Grant funds may not be used to replace state or local funds that would, in the absence of federal
label: BODY

text: assistance, be available or forthcoming.  Instead, grant funds must be used to increase the total amount
label: BODY

text: of other funds available for the grantee agency’s use.
label: BODY

text: A grant recipient may not use federal grant funds to defray any costs that the recipient is already
label: BODY

text: obligated to pay.  For example, if a grantee, prior to applying to participate in the grant program, had
label: BODY

text: committed to purchase 10 new computers for crime analysis, then the grantee must purchase those 10
label: BODY

text: computers in addition to any computers approved in the grant budget.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 3
label: BODY

text: INSTRUCTIONS FOR APPLICATION
label: H4

text: This Request for Application (RFA) provides the necessary forms, instructions, and general information
label: BODY

text: essential for those eligible to apply for grant funds. To receive the maximum number of points available,
label: BODY

text: the application MUST BE COMPLETED CORRECTLY.
label: BODY

text: Mail to or Hand-deliver to:
label: BODY

text: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY
label: H4

text: OFFICE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE
label: H4

text: 1535 OLD HOT SPRINGS ROAD #10
label: BODY

text: CARSON CITY, NV 89711-0910
label: BODY

text: to: Map to OCJA - 1535 Hot Springs Road
label: BODY

text: Each Application must be securely stapled in the top left-hand corner.  Use 12 point font when preparing
label: BODY

text: the Application.
label: BODY

text: • DO NOT bind Applications in notebooks, plastic bindings, or specially printed covers.
label: BODY

text: • DO NOT attach supplemental information (i.e. reports, booklets, etc.)
label: BODY

text: Application Packet  -  Original and four copies (stapled)of the  complete Request for Application
label: HH3

text: must include all of the following on the forms provided:
label: BODY

text: Part   1.
label: BODY

text: Title Page (4 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   2.
label: BODY

text: General Overview (10 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   3.
label: BODY

text: Problem Statement (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   4.
label: BODY

text: Goals and Objectives (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   5.
label: BODY

text: Method of Accomplishment (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   6.
label: BODY

text: Evaluation/Internal Assessment (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   7.
label: BODY

text: Sustainment (5 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   8.
label: BODY

text: Statement of Coordination (4 points)
label: BODY

text: Part   9.
label: BODY

text: Budget Information (itemized and narrative) (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Part 10.
label: HH3

text: Signed Certifications (2 points)
label: BODY

text: Fiscal Responsibilities - All recipients of federal funding are required to establish and maintain
label: HH3

text: accounting systems and financial records to accurately account for funds awarded to them.   Accounting
label: BODY

text: systems for all federal projects must ensure the following:
label: BODY

text: • PSN funds are NOT commingled with funds from other federal grant sources.
label: BODY

text: • The accounting system presents and classifies historical cost of the grant as required for
label: BODY

text: budgetary and auditing purposes.
label: BODY

text: • Funds specifically budgeted and/or received for one project cannot be used to support
label: BODY

text: another.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: All grant awards are subject to audits during and within three years after the grant award period has
label: BODY

text: closed.
label: BODY

text: Allowable Expenses (check with a Program Manager if you have questions)
label: HH3

text: • Project personnel salaries and benefits, including overtime pay.
label: BODY

text: • Equipment necessary for implementation of the program.
label: BODY

text: • Building rental.
label: BODY

text: • Project personnel travel/training.
label: BODY

text: • Supplies & Operating expenses directly related to project operation.
label: BODY

text: • Professional services (including contractors and consultants).
label: BODY

text: Unallowable Expenses (not limited to the following – check with a Program Manager)
label: HH3

text: • Business Cards
label: BODY

text: • Late Charges
label: BODY

text: • Audit Services
label: BODY

text: • Membership Dues
label: BODY

text: • Newspaper Subscriptions
label: BODY

text: • Indirect Costs
label: BODY

text: • Land/Building Acquisition
label: BODY

text: • Badges
label: BODY

text: • Construction
label: BODY

text: • Rental Cars - unless previously justified and approved by OCJA
label: BODY

text: • Bonuses, Commissions, Gifts and Incentives
label: BODY

text: • Military-type Equipment
label: BODY

text: • Lobbying
label: BODY

text: • Fund Raising
label: BODY

text: • Legal Fees
label: BODY

text: • Supplanting: federal funds must be used to supplement existing funds for program
label: BODY

text: activities and not replace those funds which have been appropriated for the same purpose
label: BODY

text: • Any expenditure not directly related to the program
label: BODY

text: • Sales tax
label: BODY

text: • Gun locks (for details, see www.projectchildsafe.org ).
label: BODY

text: • Confidential funds
label: BODY

text: • Gun buy-back programs
label: BODY

text: • Air-time to run the national public service announcements “Mothers,” “Sentenced,” and
label: BODY

text: “Family Prison.”

text: GRANT PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS
label: H4

text: READ CAREFULLY
label: HH1

text: CONTACT PROGRAM MANAGER FOR ASSISTANCE
label: H4

text: Part 1.
label: HH2

text: TITLE PAGE (Mandatory Form) – (4 points)
label: BODY

text: Using Microsoft Word, tab through document and enter appropriate information.  Make
label: BODY

text: sure the budgeted numbers are the same as on the completed budget application pages.
label: BODY

text: DO NOT ALTER FORM
label: BODY

text: DO NOT CREATE YOUR OWN FORM OR APPLICATION WILL BE RETURNED
label: BODY

text: TO YOU
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: PSN Title Page
label: BODY

text: Part 2.
label: HH2

text: GENERAL OVERVIEW / INTRODUCTION – (10 points)
label: H4

text: This area is to outline the main focus of your grant program, giving overall details of
label: BODY

text: your program and what your program will accomplish.  Statistical information is not
label: BODY

text: necessary in this section.  If this is a continuation program, include past and present
label: BODY

text: accomplishments and future plans. Be brief.  Be specific.  Avoid jargon and spell out
label: BODY

text: acronyms.  Keep it simple. Establish who you are and what your project will address.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Overview section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Limit to 1 1/2 typewritten pages, single spaced, 12 point font
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 6
label: BODY

text: Part 3.
label: HH3

text: PROBLEM STATEMENT – (15 points)
label: BODY

text: The problem statement is a written presentation that describes all aspects of a problem
label: BODY

text: including its nature, magnitude, severity, rate of change, persons/entities affected, and
label: BODY

text: geographic scope.  The problem statement must clearly describe and substantiate the
label: BODY

text: overall issue(s) to be addressed by the project.
label: BODY

text: The problem statement should be in narrative form and include, but not necessarily be
label: BODY

text: limited to, the following:
label: BODY

text: a description of the geographic areas (s) affected;
label: BODY

text: a description of the problem and contributing factors;
label: BODY

text: documentation of the problem (statistical data);
label: BODY

text: who the problem affects and the consequences;
label: BODY

text: under what circumstances the problem occurs;
label: BODY

text: other efforts presently being made to assist in alleviating the problem
label: BODY

text: (existing programs or services);
label: BODY

text: an explanation of how the project will address the problem and work toward a
label: BODY

text: solution.
label: BODY

text: The problem statement should include appropriate and most recent statistics (including
label: BODY

text: sources of information) which document the problem (i.e. arrest rates, conviction rates,
label: BODY

text: probation rates, incarceration rates, number of individuals receiving treatment, etc.)
label: BODY

text: Demonstrate rates of increase or decrease in the problem by showing the percentage of
label: BODY

text: change for a period of time covering at least two or more years.  Document percentages
label: BODY

text: of change with actual numbers (i.e., From 2005 to 2006, drug arrests increased 100%;
label: BODY

text: 2005 - 100 arrests; 2006 - 200 arrests). Reflect these in your objectives.  Include
label: BODY

text: reference sources (footnotes) when needed.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Problem Statement section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Limit your problem statement to 2 typewritten pages, single spaced, 12 pt. Font
label: BODY

text: IMPORTANT
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 7
label: BODY

text: Part 4.
label: HH3

text: GOALS AND OBJECTIVES – (15 points)
label: BODY

text: Project Goals:  This section should contain a separate discussion of each of the program goals and its
label: H4

text: accompanying objectives.  The goals are general statements of the desired results or anticipated
label: BODY

text: outcome of the program.  They should address the problem identified in the problem statement.  The
label: BODY

text: goals should be generic enough to encompass more than one project and be both realistic and
label: BODY

text: achievable.  Goals should NOT be stated in measurable terms.
label: BODY

text: • What do you want to achieve?
label: BODY

text: • Explain the goal(s) of the project in simple, straightforward terms.  One or two overall goals
label: BODY

text: are sufficient.
label: BODY

text: • The goal(s) should identify intended impacts or outcomes and the results the program has
label: BODY

text: been established to achieve.
label: BODY

text: • Each goal should have one or more measurable objective describing how you intend to
label: BODY

text: reach that goal.
label: BODY

text: • Be realistic.
label: BODY

text: • State your goals in such a way a determination of whether or not they are being achieved is
label: BODY

text: possible.
label: BODY

text: • Your goals MUST tie into your problem statement and outcome evaluation.
label: BODY

text: Project Objectives:  Each goal should have no more than four objectives.  The objectives are the
label: BODY

text: specific approaches to achieving each of the goals.  Objectives focus on the methods/activities to be used
label: BODY

text: to address the problem; they MUST be clearly stated, realistic, and measurable.   Use the statistics from
label: BODY

text: the Problem Statement.  The measurements will be used in the evaluation of the project. The
label: BODY

text: accomplishment of objectives should result in the achievement of the goals they support. OBJECTIVES
label: BODY

text: THAT ARE NOT MEASUREABLE WILL BE CAUSE FOR REJECTION OF YOUR APPLICATION.
label: BODY

text: Answer these questions in each objective:
label: BODY

text: WHAT you will do?
label: BODY

text: WHO will do the tasks?
label: BODY

text: WHEN will the activity be implemented?
label: BODY

text: HOW will they do it and HOW will they measure it?
label: BODY

text: INCLUDE a timetable; it demonstrates you have thought your program through.
label: BODY

text: AVOID the words might, if, could, should, would.
label: BODY

text: AVOID the words “To Provide”.  This is always a method to achieve the objective.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 8
label: BODY

text: Objectives describe:
label: BODY

text: • How you will achieve your goal(s)?
label: BODY

text: • The activities necessary to accomplish your goals.
label: BODY

text: • The objective in terms that can be measured, qualified, quantified and evaluated.
label: BODY

text: • A timetable, where applicable, of when each objective will be met.
label: BODY

text: To see an example of a measurable objective,   click here
label: BODY

text: Tip:   Your goals and objectives MUST tie into the evaluation process.  Both of these sections will
label: BODY

text: connect with your quarterly progress reports. Don’t have too many objectives, i.e. more than
label: BODY

text: four is too many. Remember you must report on the progress of every objective quarterly.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Goals & Objectives section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Part 5.
label: HH2

text: METHODS OF ACCOMPLISHMENT – (15 points)
label: BODY

text: You MUST reference your goals and objectives and statistics from the Problem
label: BODY

text: Statement.  This section should describe the activities you will use to accomplish the
label: BODY

text: objectives.  Include the performance measures required by BJA.  Use the following
label: BODY

text: guidelines:
label: BODY

text: • Read your Problem Statement
label: BODY

text: • Read the required Performance Measures.
label: BODY

text: • How do you intend to solve the problem or improve the situation?
label: BODY

text: • Discuss how your approach method will improve the situation and explain why this
label: BODY

text: activity is being pursued.
label: BODY

text: • Provide a narrative showing how PSN funding will impact or solve the stated
label: BODY

text: problem.
label: BODY

text: • A specific need for training must be identified.
label: BODY

text: • What activities will you implement to reach an objective?
label: BODY

text: • These must tie to each goal and objective.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 9
label: BODY

text: Limit your Methods of Accomplishment to 2 typewritten pages, single spaced, 12 pt. font
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Methods section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Part 6.
label: HH2

text: PROJECT EVALUATION/INTERNAL ASSESSMENT – (15 points)
label: BODY

text: The evaluation must tie to the objectives and the BJA established performance measures.
label: BODY

text: If you have difficulty in determining what criteria to use in evaluating your program,
label: BODY

text: better take another look at your objectives and how you plan to measure them.
label: BODY

text: • How will you know the project is working?
label: BODY

text: • How will you determine if you are meeting your objectives?
label: BODY

text: Every project design must include an evaluation plan to determine whether the project is
label: BODY

text: accomplishing its objectives.  The evaluation should be designed to provide an objective
label: BODY

text: and independent assessment of the effectiveness or usefulness of the program.
label: BODY

text: Provide a plan to determine whether the project accomplished the goals and objectives it
label: BODY

text: was designed to meet.  The plan should present the qualifications of the evaluator.
label: BODY

text: Describe the criteria used to evaluate the project’s effectiveness. Consider using an
label: BODY

text: outside evaluator if at all possible.  This will make your results more credible.
label: BODY

text: When submitting a final report, you must also submit your evaluation of the
label: BODY

text: project.  Both are due 45 days after the end of the project period.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Evaluation section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Tip:
label: BODY

text: There should be no surprises in your methods.  Objectives fully disclose your intentions
label: BODY

text: and your methods are simply an extension of your objectives.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 10
label: BODY

text: Part 7.
label: HH3

text: SUSTAINMENT (5 points)
label: BODY

text: How will your project continue operation when grant funds are no longer available?  There is no
label: BODY

text: guarantee grant funds will be available for your project in the future.  Provide a detailed summary
label: BODY

text: of the plan to continue operations when these funds are not available or are significantly reduced.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Sustainment section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Part 8.
label: HH2

text: STATEMENT OF COORDINATION – (4 points)
label: BODY

text: Will other agencies be involved or have an interest in your program?   Who are they and what
label: BODY

text: are their roles?
label: BODY

text: Multi-jurisdictional task forces must provide a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU).  MOU
label: BODY

text: must contain details as to the disposition of equipment purchased with grant funds if the task
label: BODY

text: force is dissolved.  MOU must be updated and signed annually.  If a State of Nevada agency,
label: BODY

text: an Inter-local Agreement must be submitted in lieu of an MOU.
label: BODY

text: Many programs succeed due to the collaborated efforts of federal, state and/or local criminal
label: BODY

text: justice, education, prevention, treatment and law enforcement agencies.  Describe your efforts to
label: BODY

text: coordinate, cooperate, or work with other entities to ensure the success of the project activities.
label: BODY

text: This will reflect favorably on your application.
label: BODY

text: To begin writing the Coordination section of your application, click here
label: BODY

text: Return to Instructions Page
label: BODY

text: Part 9.
label: HH2

text: BUDGET INFORMATION – (15 points)
label: BODY

text: BUDGET COVER PAGE - All project costs MUST relate directly to and be necessary
label: BODY

text: for the tasks described in the Methods.  The Budget Cover Page will be a simple line
label: BODY

text: item budget identifying the following categories as they apply to your program:
label: BODY

text: 1. Personnel costs (all costs related to salary, benefits, etc.)
label: BODY

text: 2. Consultant/Contractual Services (costs must not exceed the federal limitation of
label: BODY

text: $450 for an 8-hour day or $56.25 per hour)
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 11
label: BODY

text: 3. Travel AND Training Costs (travel, transportation, room costs, meals, parking, etc.)
label: BODY

text: Note:  State per diem rates will prevail unless local rates are less.
label: BODY

text: 4. Supplies/Operating Expenses
label: BODY

text: 5. Equipment
label: BODY

text: Miscellaneous and Other are not considered costs.  If these terms are used in any category, the
label: BODY

text: corresponding cost will be deducted.
label: BODY

text: Round off budget figures - do not use cents.   (Example:  $170.57 will be $171.00)  All budgets
label: BODY

text: are subject to OCJA modifications and approval.  Fill out ALL pages completely.  Estimate ALL
label: BODY

text: costs to the nearest dollar.
label: BODY

text: MAKE SURE THE NUMBERS ADD UP CORRECTLY AND MATCH THE TITLE PAGE.
label: BODY

text: The budget form contains space for the budget justification (use additional sheet if necessary).
label: BODY

text: This justification should include the details of how the amounts presented in the budget were
label: BODY

text: determined.  Specific instructions for completing each section of the budget are included on the
label: BODY

text: budget pages.  If you have questions or concerns related to how to complete the budget pages,
label: BODY

text: please call (775) 687-3700 or an OCJA Program Manager for assistance (contacts).
label: BODY

text: When reviewing your budget, ask “Is this budget reasonable?  Are these items necessary to the
label: BODY

text: success of our program?” If you previously had a PSN grant, look at the budget for the last 2
label: BODY

text: years versus this requested budget.  Are you duplicating purchases from previous years?
label: BODY

text: Each Budget Category must be addressed separately as follows:
label: HH1

text: Category A - PERSONNEL COSTS
label: HH3

text: This category refers to wages and fringe benefits for regular or part-time salaried project
label: BODY

text: employees.  Other persons working on the project who are not on the regular payroll must be
label: BODY

text: classified either as contractual or consultant. This category also includes overtime for approved
label: BODY

text: program activities.
label: BODY

text: AVOID SUPPLANTING -- Do not request federal funding for an employee already on the
label: BODY

text: payroll unless he/she will be replaced  by another person who is hired to augment regular agency
label: BODY

text: staff during the time the existing employee spends working on project activities.  A regular
label: BODY

text: employee, however, may be paid overtime for time worked on the project.  Salaries may not
label: BODY

text: exceed those normally paid for comparable positions in the community and/or the unit of
label: BODY

text: government associated with the project.
label: BODY

text: PSN Program Application
label: BODY

text: Page 12
label: BODY

text: Instructions for Completing Budget Forms
label: BODY

text: Direct Salaries and Overtime - Write in the title or position of each new employee or each
label: BODY

text: existing employee who will earn overtime for grant-related activities or will be compensated
label: BODY

text: with grant funds during training sessions.  Across from each position/job title listed, write in the
label: BODY

text: annual salary for employee or the overtime wage (dollar/hour) for the position, percent of time
label: BODY

text: to be devoted to the project (for a new employee) or number of overtime hours and the total cost
label: BODY

text: for the position.  At the bottom of Section I, write in the total of the funds requested.
label: BODY

text: Fringe Benefits - All fringe benefits are to be listed on the budget pages and will be included in
label: BODY

text: the total personnel costs.  For fringes not listed, add under “other” and describe, i.e. uniform
label: BODY

text: allowance, etc.
label: BODY

text: Total Personnel – The total should auto-calculate; however, if it doesn’t, write in the total
label: BODY

text: requested or call OCJA for assistance.
label: BODY

text: Personnel Budget Narrative - A brief statement explaining the cost basis for each position.
label: BODY

text: Explain how each position is related to and essential to the project. Explain why the grant should
label: BODY

text: pay for the personnel requested.  Are they essential to the success of the project?
label: BODY

text: To begin typing Personnel Budget Narrative, click here
label: BODY

text: Category B - CONSULTANT/CONTRACTUAL SERVICES
label: HH3

text: 1. Individuals - Complete Section 1 for individuals not on the regular payroll who will be reimbursed
label: H4

text: for professional services.
label: BODY

text: a. Consultant Fees - For each individual consultant, enter the name, if known, service to be
label: HH3

text: provided, hourly fee and estimated time on the project in hours.  Fees must not exceed federal
label: BODY

text: guidelines ($450 per 8 hr. day or $56.25/hour).
label: BODY

text: b. Consultant Expenses - List all expenses to be paid from the grant to individual consultants in
label: BODY

text: addition to fees on the line number which corresponds to the line number of each consultant listed
label: BODY

text: in subsection (a).  List the rates used to calculate travel, meal and other expenses.  Cost may not
label: BODY

text: exceed the state rate.
label: BODY

text: c. Total Consultant Costs - The total should auto-calculate; however, if it doesn’t, write in the total
label: BODY

text: requested.
label: BODY

text: Page 13

text: 2. Consultants and Contractors Budget Narrative  A narrative  is required explaining the basis or
label: HH3

label: BODY

text: the project. Detail costs and necessity to the project in the budget narrative section.

label: HH3

text: Category  C - Travel Expenses
label: BODY

text: 1. In-State Travel - List each anticipated in-state trip outside the local jurisdiction stating the
label: HH2

text: purpose of the trip, destination, and total. Breakdown of per diem costs must be included.
label: BODY

text: 2. Out-of-State Travel - List each anticipated out-of-state trip stating the purpose of the trip,
label: HH3

text: destination, and total cost (e.g. training, interview, operations, etc.)  A breakdown of per diem
label: BODY

text: costs must be included. Three persons maximum allowed per trip.
label: BODY

text: 3. Total Travel Budget - The total should auto-calculate; however, if it doesn’t, write in the total
label: H4

text: requested or call OCJA for assistance.
label: BODY

text: 4. Travel Budget Narrative - A narrative explaining the purpose of the travel and how it relates to
label: H4

text: the project.
label: BODY

text: Break out the costs of each in-state and out-of-state trip separately to show the specific costs of
label: BODY

text: transportation, food, lodging, and other expenses.  Remember, costs may not exceed the state rates.
label: BODY

text: Indicate how/why the in-state and out-of-state trips are essential to the success of the project.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: PM.
label: BODY

text: Dinner - Dinner may be claimed if travel status is 6:30 PM or later.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: reimbursement.)

text: **  Excessive lodging rates must be justified and have prior OCJA approval.

text: Category D - Supplies and operating expenses

text: 1. Supplies/Operating - This Section includes office supplies, forms, project supplies, repairs or
label: HH2

text: maintenance supplies, and equipment items costing under $500; essentially, material which is
label: BODY

text: expendable or consumed during the course of the project.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: cost, and total cost.  Explain how you came up with the amount you are requesting.

label: BODY

text: consultant type services.

label: BODY

text: Category E – Equipment

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: A complete Application addresses each of the sections listed above.  If you should have any

label: BODY

text: Appeals
label: HH2

text: Applicants whose requests are not funded have the right to appeal the decision.  Any applicant
label: BODY

text: whose Application has been filed according to the rules governing the grant process, and who is
label: BODY

text: aggrieved by the awards made pursuant to these rules, may request an appeal based on showing
label: BODY

text: that the rules governing the grant selection process have not been properly applied.
label: BODY

text: Requests for appeal must be filed with U.S. Attorney, District of Nevada, 333 Las Vegas Blvd
label: BODY

text: South, Suite 5000, Las Vegas, NV  89101, within seven working days of the notification of
label: BODY

text: denial.  Requests for appeal must be in writing and clearly state how the Office of Criminal
label: BODY

text: Justice Assistance or the review committee erred in following the administrative rules governing
label: BODY

text: the grant process or the procedure outlined in the program RFA. The review will be conducted as
label: BODY

text: expeditiously as possible so all funds can be distributed in a timely fashion.  This procedure
label: BODY

text: concludes the review process at the administrative level.
label: BODY

text: Avoid common pitfalls B
label: HH3

text: • Ensure budget figures are mathematically correct, and the total of the budget summary matches
label: BODY

text: the total on the title page;
label: BODY

text: • Observe page limitations;
label: BODY

text: • Use standard type size (12 point font);
label: BODY

text: • Respond to all sections of the Application;
label: BODY

text: • Remember any funds referred to as miscellaneous/other in the budget section will be disallowed;
label: BODY

text: • Supply the required number of copies (one original and four (4) copies), without binding. If all
label: BODY

text: required copies are not included, your grant cannot be accepted.
label: BODY

text: HELPFUL HINTS
label: H2

text: To help write a successful proposal, ask yourself the following questions.
label: BODY

text: Have you:
label: BODY

text: Read the solicitation carefully?
label: BODY

text: Followed all instructions, including:
label: BODY

text: a. The recommended format?
label: BODY

text: b. The narrative content and length?
label: BODY

text: c. The required font, spacing, etc?
label: BODY

text: Provided all required information, i.e.
label: BODY

text: a. Completed all the forms?
label: BODY

text: b. Filled in all the blanks?
label: BODY

text: c. Obtained all official signatures?
label: BODY

text: Developed a proper narrative that:
label: BODY

text: a. Defined the problem?
label: BODY

text: b. Specified proposed actions?
label: BODY

text: c. Stated how actions will solve the problem?
label: BODY

text: d. Described evaluation criteria?
label: BODY

text: e. Included source information for factual citations?
label: BODY

text: Used clear English, in particular:
label: BODY

text: a. Avoided acronyms, unless defined?
label: BODY

text: b. Avoided technical jargon?
label: BODY

text: Developed a budget that contained the costs of the proposal? Are your costs:
label: BODY

text: a. Reasonable?
label: BODY

text: b. Allowable?
label: BODY

text: c. Cost effective in relation to the proposed activities?
label: BODY

text: d. Accurately calculated?
label: BODY

text: Have you created measurable objectives?  Are they within the specified guidelines?
label: BODY

text: Made all of the required copies?
label: BODY

text: Finished by the deadline?
label: BODY

text: Describe what other agencies/departments/resources will be involved in your program and how they

text: will assist in your efforts to achieve your goals.  Begin typing below this box.

text: This section is for your information only and should not be returned with your grant application.
label: BODY

text: Example One
label: BODY

text: Goal:  To maximize Court resources and reduce recidivism in each Court jurisdiction.
label: HH3

text: Problem Statement:  The applicant should document the number of recidivists in each Court, then
label: HH3

text: compare that number to existing and meaningful data, i.e., historical recidivism rates for that Court
label: BODY

text: or, to statewide and national averages or, averages for similarly sized jurisdictions.  If your
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction’s numbers are right-on with others (not notably higher), then you don’t have a problem
label: BODY

text: and the use of grant funds here is not advised, since recidivism will always exist and yours is “as
label: BODY

text: good as it gets.”
label: BODY

text: Your goal actually contains two problems:  the first is recidivism and the second, Court resources.
label: BODY

text: We cannot assume that recidivism by itself is the source of the Court’s overwhelm.
label: BODY

text: So, you’ll also need to measure the impact that recidivists have on the Court. Your problem
label: BODY

text: statement for this element should demonstrate that, of the total man-hours (account for Judges,
label: BODY

text: prosecutors and support staff) per week/month/year the Court expends, xx% is spent dealing with
label: BODY

text: recidivists.  Compare that to other Courts’ data as suggested above.
label: BODY

text: Objective 1:  Now that you’ve measured the number of recidivists, you can measure the impact the
label: BODY

text: proposed program will have on that statistical problem. Your measurable objective should answer
label: BODY

text: these five important questions:
label: BODY

text: Who
label: BODY

text: Will do what
label: BODY

text: When
label: BODY

text: How much
label: BODY

text: As measured by . . .
label: BODY

text: So, an objective for this program might look like this:
label: BODY

text: The number of recidivists appearing before the Court [who] will be reduced [will do what] by 8%
label: BODY

text: [how much] in fiscal year 2003 [when], as measured by an ongoing analysis of Court records [as
label: BODY

text: measured by].
label: BODY

text: In order for this objective to have merit:
label: BODY

text: • The applicant must have measured the number of recidivists historically.
label: BODY

text: • The applicant must forecast impact (a reduction of recidivism) based on real-world research
label: BODY

text: of similar programs’ impacts, (not to be confused with fantasy and “I think I can” assertions.)
label: BODY

text: • The applicant must track, on an ongoing basis, incidents of recidivism during the period of
label: BODY

text: grant funding.
label: BODY

text: The end result is an objective proposal in which the definition of success is agreed to in advance.
label: BODY

text: Oversimplified, it reads like this:  “The Court sees 1,800 cases per year of which 400 are recidivists.
label: BODY

text: The proposed program will reduce this number to 300 for a total annual recidivist case load of 1,400,
label: BODY

text: and we’re going to prove it by counting the number of recidivists seen by the Courts next year.”
label: BODY

text: It is important you distinguish between “process objectives” and “outcome objectives.”  We MUST
label: BODY

text: have measurable “outcome objectives” to see what progress is being made in your program.
label: BODY

text: Process objectives may be very useful but should only appear in the Methods section of your
label: BODY

text: proposal so they are not confused with the results of your proposed.
label: BODY

text: Example of a Process Objective (not acceptable in your application)
label: HH3

text: Ten Narcotic officers will complete a 5 week training program by the end of the 2006 academic
label: BODY

text: year, measured by program attendance records.
label: BODY

text: Example of an Outcome Objective (acceptable in your application)
label: HH3

text: Ten Narcotic officers [who] will increase their grant writing skills [what] by 20% [how much] by the
label: BODY

text: end of the 2006 fiscal year [when] as measured by pre and post program test scores [as measured
label: BODY

text: by].
label: BODY

text: If you can’t answers all of the five questions, then you have a Process Objective which will cause
label: BODY

text: your application to be rejected.
label: BODY

text: Continue to writing Goals & Objectives
label: BODY

text: Go to Top  of Guidelines-

text: Project Title:  Enter a brief descriptive title.  A previously funded application should have the same title it used in

label: BODY
